IDBTransaction.summary: The IDBTransaction interface of the IndexedDB API provides a static, asynchronous transaction on a database using event handler attributes. All reading and writing of data is done within transactions. You use to start transactions, IDBTransaction to set the mode of the transaction (e.g., is it readonly or readwrite), and you access an to make a request. You can also use an IDBTransaction object to abort transactions.

remarks.para: Transactions are started when the transaction is created, not when the first request is placed; for example consider this:
After the code is executed the object store should contain the value "2", since trans2 should run after trans1.

A transaction alternates between active and inactive states between event loop tasks. It's active in the task when it was created, and in each task of the requests' success or error event handlers. It's inactive in all other tasks, in which case placing requests will fail. If no new requests are placed when the transaction is active, and there are no other outstanding requests, the transaction will automatically commit.

-Using IndexedDB

-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:

interface returns a of names
of objects.

IDBTransactionError.summary:
The IDBTransaction.error property of the interface
returns the type of error when there is an unsuccessful transaction.

IDBTransactionError.value:
A containing the relevant error, or null if there are none.It can be a reference to the same error as the request object that raised it, or a transaction
failure (for example QuotaExceededError).This property is null if the transaction is not finished, or is finished and
was successfully committed.

IDBTransactionCommit.summary: The commit() method of the interface commits the transaction if it is called on an active transaction.

remarks.para: Note that commit() doesn't normally have to be called â€” a transaction will automatically commit when all outstanding requests have been satisfied and no new requests have been made. commit() can be used to start the commit process without waiting for events from outstanding requests to be dispatched.
If it is called on a transaction that is not active, it throws an InvalidStateError .

IDBTransactionAbort.summary: The abort event is fired when an IndexedDB transaction is aborted.

remarks.para: This can happen for any of the following reasons:
This non-cancelable event bubbles to the associated object.
-Using IndexedDB

IDBTransactionError.summary: The error event is fired on IDBTransaction when a request returns an error and the event bubbles up to the transaction object.

blockquote.para: To handle all the ways a transaction can fail, consider listening for the event instead.

remarks.para: -Using IndexedDB

IDBTransactionMode.summary:
The mode read-only property of the
interface returns the current mode for accessing the
data in the object stores in the scope of the transaction (i.e., is the mode to be
read-only, or do you want to write to the object stores?) The default value is
readonly.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBTransactionMode.value:
An object defining the mode for isolating access to
data in the current object stores:
A string defining the mode for isolating access to data in the current object stores.
The following values are available:

IDBTransactionComplete.summary: The complete event of the IndexedDB API is fired when the transaction has successfully committed, which is either after you explicit call or when all requests have been successfully completed, and after handling their results, no new requests have been placed. See for more information.

remarks.para: -Using IndexedDB

IDBTransactionAbort.summary:
The abort() method of the
interface rolls back all the changes to objects in the database associated with this
transaction.

remarks.para:
All pending objects created during this transaction have
their attribute set to an AbortError .

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBTransactionObjectStore.summary:
The objectStore() method of the
interface returns an object store that has already been
added to the scope of this transaction.

remarks.para:
Every call to this method on the same transaction object, with the same name, returns
the same instance. If this method is called on a different
transaction object, a different instance is returned.

-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

IDBTransactionObjectStore.returns: An object for accessing an object store.

IDBTransactionDurability.summary:
The durability read-only property of the interface returns the durability hint the transaction was created with.
This is a hint to the user agent of whether to prioritize performance or durability when committing the transaction.

remarks.para: The value of this property is defined in the options.durability parameter when creating a transaction using .

IDBTransactionDb.summary:
The db read-only property of the interface returns the database connection
with which this transaction is associated.
